item.description:
ORION - yours to conquer. Once just a distant constellation, Orion is now being explored and colonized. Will you lead your alliance to victory or suffer defeat at the hands of your enemies?

Conquest of Orion is a team-based card game played over several rounds of conflicts. For each conflict, players play a single card and then evaluate the winner. However, technologies and leaders have special abilities that will influence the outcome of each conflict. Through careful card play and strategy, players will work with their partner to lead their alliance to glory!

In this game players are dwarves, trying to climb the magic mountain. In order to move, dwarves have to solve various tasks. On their way they gather magic feathers and diamonds. Magic feathers are used to fly over the obstacles dwarves run in. When the first dwarf reaches the top of the mountain, game ends and the player who gathered most diamonds wins.

This roll and move game teaches young players mathematics. In order to move players have to perform such arithmetic operations as addition, subtraction and division. Also it improves decision making skill. Players have to decide whether to gather diamond and fall into the pit (move backwards) or use magic feather and fly over the pit leaving the diamond where it is.

name.value: Fancy Nancy Ooh La La Tea Party Game

item.description: "Ooh la la, it's time for a tea party!" No one knows fancy like Nancy! Join Fancy Nancy in this fun-filled tea party game where players spin a spinner to collect Colorforms Stick-Ons and place them on their special tea party play scene boards, competing to be the first to place all six respectively.

Balancing Cactus is a children's dexterity game. First the cactus base is placed in the center of the play area. Players then take turns placing wooden cactus pieces, or stems, onto the base or onto other stems that have already been placed. A player who causes the cactus to fall over is eliminated and play is restarted with all of the remaining players until only one player, the winner, remains.

item.description:
User Description

Sir Harry & the Dinosaurs is a set of miniatures rules for Dinosaur Hunting.

The game takes place in the year of 1878 and is about "Sir Harold Fortherington Smyth" exhibition to the jungles if India and his attmpts to capture some dinosaurs for the "British Zoological Society".

The object of the game is to capture as many dinosaurs as possible, either before your figures are killed or in a set ammout of time or as set out by a scenario (divised by the players). The rules can be played as solo game or multiple player game.

The suggested miniatures for these rules are 15mm through 25mm figurs could be used. Also scenary and dice (D4, D6, and a D10) will be needed to play.

The rules was first published in Ragnarok, issue 39.

There's a big mess on the table! Who can clean up the cards the fastest, while also lining up cards that match one another?

In Connect the Thoughts – first released as Kuddelmuddel, which is German for "hodgepodge" – players try to put together chains of cards in order to score points. To set up the game, the players scatter the 80 cards in the deck face down on the table and place the bell within reach of all players. Everyone then simultaneously starts looking at face-down cards one by one. You can place the first card you see face up to start a row in front of you. To place another card next to this first one, whether on the left or right, the newly placed card must have at least one image in common with the card already in place.

As soon as a player has seven matching cards in a row, she rings the bell. If she goofed up, she sits out the round until another player creates a row; if she did everything correctly, she scoops up those cards and places them in a pile beside her while all other players reshuffle their cards into those that remain on the table.

The game ends whenever the last card is taken from the center of the table. Whoever has collected the most cards (i.e., rows) wins!

name.value: Gordon Solie's Championship Wrestling Trivia Game

item.description: The object of Gordon Solie's Championship Wrestling Trivia Game, which includes 1,200 trivia questions, is for players to move their respective marker once around the game board and diagonally up the Championship Match spaces into the center of the Championship Belt. Players move around the board and attempt to answer trivia questions along the way, earning additional rolls of the die and thus advancing more quickly to their home corner and the Championship Match. The first player correctly answering the appropriate trivia question after moving inside the Championship Belt wins.

name.value: The Very Hungry Caterpillar Match and Munch Game

item.description:
Players trade, collect and match five of the Very Hungry Caterpillar's food tiles in various sequences, for example five oranges or four strawberries plus an apple. A winning combination is traded for a butterfly token and the player's hand is replenished. The first player to collect three butterfly tokens wins. This game is intended for ages 3 and up so no reading is required.

Wild cards, which can fill in for one fruit tile per hand, are the various foods the caterpillar ate on Saturday in the Eric Carle story such as a cupcake or sausage.

The game parts fit in a soft bag that looks like the caterpillar. The game contains 55 food item tiles, 10 round butterfly tokens, a card showing the winning combinations, and a small directions leaflet.

Chicago Cubs Special Edition
112 Custom cards feature Derrek Lee, Aramis Ramirez, Carlos Zambrano, Michael Barrett, Jacques Jones and other Cubs stars.
Same great UNO play PLUS exclusive Acquisition card and rule.
This game is similar to the traditional game of Jacks. Instead of 10 jacks, there are 8 pig figurines that must be picked up while bouncing a ball.

High Side is a casino table game using both cards and dice.

From the game description:
"High Side is a table game that accommodates five or six players on a standard blackjack table, depending on layout utilization.

High Side is similar to Baccarat in that players do not compete against the dealer or other players. Instead, players win based on the comparison of two community hand values.

The game uses six standard decks of 52 playing cards per deck dealt from a shoe and two Pai Gow dice cups, each containing a single standard six sided die."

From the rules:
"The object of High|Side is to bet on the higher of two
hand values.

The first hand value is determined by the roll of two dice.
The second hand value is determined by the draw of a single
card. Card values equal the number on the card with Aces
playing as 1, Jacks as 11, Queens as 12 and Kings as 13.
The winning hand is the High|Side and pays even money."

In Duck-A-Roo, the little ducks quack happily and swim around the pond. They all want to follow their mother in order to be good ducks, so they try to keep pushing their way to the front of the line – and with your help, they'll make it there!

To set up the game, place the twenty color tiles face down in the center of the table, then place the mama duck, with the three baby ducks in a row behind her. On a player's turn, she reveals the color of one of the face-down tiles. If it matches the color of the duck at the back of the line, she keeps the tile and scoots the duck forward so that it's right behind its mother. The player takes another turn, searching for a tile to match the color of the duck now at the back of the line. If the player doesn't find a tile of the proper color, her turn ends.

Once the final tile has been claimed from the center of the table, the game ends. Whoever has collected the most tiles wins!

Easy Under Over is a casino table game involving both dice and cards.

From the game manual:
"Easy Over Under is a table game that accommodates six players on a standard blackjack table. The game uses at least one standard deck of 52 playing cards, two six sided dice and a pai gow dice cup. The cards are assigned numerical values with Ace = 1, each of the pip cards according to their face values, Jacks = 11, Queens = 12, and Kings = 13.

Players do not compete against the dealer or other players. The players win or lose based on the comparison of the value of their single player card to the value of the community dice roll."

Who knows best about the animals on this planet? Who knows the solitary ones, and the ones who travel in packs? Who knows their sizes, and whether they're endangered? If you do, you'll do well at Alle meine Tiere – and if not, you'll soon learn more about the animals around us.

To set up the game, someone lays out a 3x3 grid of animal cards, then sets the category deck and the remainder of the animal deck next to this grid.

On a turn, the active player draws a category card, which shows "height", "weight", "lifestyle" or "hazard"; the former categories will show whether you need to find cards in ascending or descending order, while the latter categories will indicate whether you need to find solo/pack animals or endangered/safe animals. Choose one of the rows in the grid, then reveal the backs of the cards, which will show whether you guessed correctly. If you did, you claim one of those cards, remove the other two from play, then replace them with new cards; if not, you turn the cards face down again, and the next player tries to find a set of animals that will fulfill that same category.

Whoever is first to collect an agreed-upon number of animal cards wins!

Kharberg is a simplified form of the moorish game Damma, but with a difference. 
The gamepieces may be moved in any given direction, so the player has the choice of eight directions for each pawn. This gives Kharberg game an edge (far more mobility) over the games where the pieces only may be moved forward.

To play KHARBERG the players need: 
12 white pawns 
12 black pawns 
1 board consisting of 25 squares (5 x 5) 
 On each square a pawn is placed. The middle square of the board is unoccupied at the start of the game. The gamepieces are placed on the board in the following order:
In front of the player the pawns of his color are placed on the first two rows. The two remaining pawns are placed on the two squares to the right of the centrepoint.

The 'black' player has the first move. Object of the game is to capture all the pawns of the opponent. Pieces are caught by jumping over the square they occupy.

Purpose of the game:
The purpose of Kharberg is to catch all the pieces of the opponent or to block them so that they can’t be moved any longer. Whoever succeeds wins the game. Draws can also occur (if both players have an equal number of game pieces on the board without the possibility of a decision).

Turn and stroke options:
Each piece can move a field in a horizontal, vertical or diagonal direction (forward and backward). Capturing pieces is done by jumping over them.
If the opponent refuses a stroke or overlooks the pawn that had to be caught, his pawn must be removed from the board (the so-called blow). The playing piece must be taken off before the player moves his own piece. If a move has already been made, the option of removal expires.

The player with the black pawns starts the game.
In the next game, the winner gets the black pieces.

Fish Cook is a simple Euro-style board game in which players take the role of chefs. The game is divided into several "days" that have two parts: Morning and Evening. In the morning, players buy ingredients from the fish market and farmer's market; in the evening, they cook recipes and earn money. The strategy revolves around buying ingredients as cheaply and efficiently as possible, in addition to stealing the good ideas of your fellow chefs.

item.description: A typical classic children's game, based on racing mechanics, where you roll the dice, move your pawn along a numbered path and follow instructions on some of the numbers, if you land on them. The theme is a mix of many farytales. The Swedish version is from the 1940s.

When venturing in Limbo at the edge of the galaxy, scouts found a new form of energy: Titanium. First experiments showed it could push back the frontiers of technology, and even open new horizons for human capabilities. This news was more than enough to stir up the greed of humankind's greatest factions. Each has sent fleets to take over nearby planets where Titanium is abundant – and even seems to be in constant expansion. From that point on, armed conflicts were bound to happen, and this war will be settled only by controlling the Titanium deposits...

As leaders of these great factions in Titanium Wars, players will purchase buildings to master new technologies and increase their earnings, build their own fleet of custom battleships to defeat their opponents, and expand their space empire. They will have to prove bold, insightful and tactful if they want any chance to win this fierce war.

name.value: Blood And Guts: Rules, Tactics, and Scenarios for Wargaming World War Two

item.description:
From the back of the book:

United States Marine Corps veteran David Hall presents a new and exciting way to experience the Second World War in Blood and Guts: Rules, Tactics, and Scenarios for Wargaming World War Two. Hall developed his tactical game system through decades of personal wargaming, and he now shares his unique system with readers everywhere. The rules are easy to learn, and the games are fast-paced. The scenarios cover almost all of the major theaters of conflict, including France 1940, the Mediterranean, the South Pacific, and the Eastern Front. A table of organization and equipment is included to assist readers in recreating wargame infantry and armor formations. Hall doesn't simply provide a set of rules; he infuses each chapter with wargame theory, tactics, and tank development. He provides the logic behind each rule and talks about how the rule design plays out the battlefield. He also shares stories and anecdotes about his early "toy soldier" days and about how he developed into a wargamer-stories sure to spark readers' memories of their own first set of soldiers.

356 pages. Photos and illustrations.

A simple but fun quiz game where all the questions concern language. It is made up bu a deck of cards. On each card are 10 questions written. They are increasingly difficult (1 easy, 10 difficult). Each player starts by answering a leve 1 question. If that is correct the player gets to answer a level 2 question and so on. If the player are unsure about the answer she can either try to answer or pass. If the answer is incorrect she has to start over at level one next time it is her turn. If she passes she start on the level she passed on. The first to answer a level 10 question wins.

name.value: Phil Dunn's Sea Battle Games Naval Wargaming 1650-1945

item.description:
From the back of the book:

'Sea Battles was a marvelously detailed book on recreating naval warfare. ' Donald Featherstone - author of over 40 books on wargaming and military history This book covers all aspects of naval wargaming with a detailed examination of the key factors affecting gunnery and damage. Chapters include: Napoleonic period rules Ironclad rules Pre-dreadnought rules World War I and II rules Map campaigns This revised edition includes new chapters, illustrations and a Sink the Bismarck game based on Dunn's concepts by the well-known military historian Paddy Griffith. The History of Wargaming Project is edited by John Curry. It aims to present the very best wargaming books and rules to a modern audience. Further details can be found at www.johncurryevents.co.uk.

266 pages. Photos and illustrations.

Statistical baseball game. Features around 400 team statistics spread over 1976 - 1991.

Choose your teams and then roll dice to reference the result on charts. Normal baseball scoring and the team who hits the most runs, wins.

Self-published statistical golf game. System designed to play very quickly, allowing for whole tournaments to be played in one evening.

Statistics for nearly 1,000 golfers are provided and around 100 courses to choose from. The statistics have been generated from the 1940's to the early 1990's. All dice rolls are compared to various charts to get the result of a tournament eventually.

Scoring is as per normal golf so the winner is the one with the lowest number of shots.

La Hache & le Feu is a cooperative boardgame for 2 players (more with the expansions) which take on the roles of courageous heroes.

During each game, the heroes embark on quests and venture into dark dungeons to battle monsters, earn gold.

With danger lurking in every shadow, combat is a necessity. For such times, La Hache & le Feu uses a dice-based system. Players use dice according to their character's abilities and weapons.

Featuring 16 modular board pieces, 5 dices, many tokens and 55 cards, etc.

name.value: Idaho Smith and the Terracotta Terror

item.description:
User Description

Idaho Smith and the Terracotta Terror is a miniatures mini game.

The game is set in 1932 and is about Idaho Smith and his travels to find the fabled white Pyramid in China. Smith finds the Pyamid but awakes evil sorecer and his army Terracotta Warriors. The aim of the game is to fight off to Terracotta army.

All the players takes the side of the explores and the Terracotta Warriors are controlled by rolling a dice on a reaction table.

The rules are simple and can be played solo if desired.

The desciption is based on the rules published in Ragnarok, issue 43.

name.value: Weather Wars: Battle for the Guzunganator

item.description:
In Weather Wars, you recruit wacky animals to your cause. Once you reach one hundred power worth of animals, or your team reaches 150 power in team play, you take control of the weather machine and win the game. Early on, only small power creatures can be played, but as the game progresses, larger, more powerful creatures come online. Each creature has an ability that triggers when it comes into play, helping your cause or causing mayhem for other players. The season card indicates what season the weather machine has forced on the world. Gather more summer creatures in summer, or more winter creatures in winter, and you'll earn a big season bonus – but watch out! At any time a Season Change Card can flip the season and ruin all your careful planning.

Weather Wars features an unusual hand mechanic - rather than drawing a card each turn, cards are played until a player only has two left in hand. These last two are then discarded and replaced with a 5-card hand. This creates subtle strategic depth - which cards should be played now, which later, and which not at all? It also gives additional meaning to any card ability that allows you to draw extra cards.

Other game features include a catchup mechanic in the form of the Season Change card, game acceleration via prerequisites for playing larger animals, and opportunities for collaboration in team play. The game plays quickly, to allow for frequent replays.

Weather Wars is a family-friendly card game for 2-4 players ages 8 and up, and takes about 20 minutes to play.

item.description:
Choose your gear. Balance your skills. Hone your strategy.

BattleBrik: The Ultimate Warrior is a tactical miniatures board game that pushes the envelope of the LEGO Games line into new strategic territory. Influenced by Ninjago, BrikWars, The Deadliest Warrior TV show, HeroScape, and other miniatures games, this game will allow you to finally find out who the Ultimate Warrior of your LEGO minfig collection is!

The base game comes with all the dice, tiles, cards, and basic warrior parts needed for 2 to 4 players to quickly start your battles. Players can also purchase "Warrior Packs" (similar to existing Ninjago blisters) or make custom warriors from their existing minifigures.

Players outfit their warrior with weapons and armor, build and balance their Skill & Gear dice, construct a Strategy deck of cards....then face off in the customizable arena!

A key concept of the game is that different colored tiles represent different skills and body locations for the warrior. Based on your warrior's balance of skills, his Skill dice will have a different number of tiles for each of the colors. Likewise, the number and color of tiles on his Gear dice will depend on which armor and weapons you choose. Finally, the experience of the warrior will help him hone his strategy by determining how many and which Strategy cards can be used.

Game play is fast and furious, with both tactical and strategic decisions. The goal of the game is to have your warrior be the last one standing in the arena.

A Basic game and an Advanced game are provided so it can be played by all ages and experience levels. Since it can be described as "easy to learn, but hard to master", it will keep both the casual beginner and grizzled wargamer engaged.

The Hungry Panda Game!
Spin the spinner and match the colours as you play the easy game with younger children, helping one another find food that pandas might like to eat. Or, flip the board and complete to see who can collect the most matching items in the family game. Then, in the bonus game, use the cards to play "Panda Pairs", but watch that you don't get stuck with the odd one out!
- From the back of the box.

Bao Qing Tian Shen An(åŒ…é’å¤©å¯©æ¡ˆ)is a party game published around the early 90's. The year is not quite sure as the old publishers didn't print the date on the games. The publisher was closed so it is hard to get the exact date.

Bao Zheng(åŒ…æ‹¯)(999-1062, also named Bao Qing Tian åŒ…é’å¤©) was a much-praised official who served during the reign of Emperor Renzong of Northern Song Dynasty in ancient China. He was respected as a fair justice. His stories are popular in Chinese people.

In each turn, a player plays a card facedown and draw a card. Players in this game would play different roles. The First player who play the Emperor become Emperor (play Emperor faceup). Then Emperor have to call out Bao Qing Tian. Other players who have Bao Qing Tian card can play it to become Bao Qing Tian. The Bao Qing Tian have to decide which player(s) are the police, Wang Zhao(çŽ‹æœ) and Ma Han(é¦¬æ¼¢), depending on their cards. AS soon as the officers are decided, The Emperor says which kind of criminals he want to get rid of (there are 4 kinds of offenders). Then the police can look at one player's hand when his turn is or catch other players' cards when they discard. Bao Qing Tian have to count the times when the police searches, but the limit is 10 searches. If the police arrests the criminal, Bao Qing Tian decides how to punish the player who holds the criminal. Otherwise, the police is punished. For example, a punishment may require player to sing a song, make a funny face, etc. At this time, if players have the mathematical symbols (add, plus, subtract, minus), they can help or afflict the criminal. Sometimes the criminal would have those symbolic cards and he can help himself. If the criminal is the Emperor, he can cancel his punishment (this is the dark side of this game).

The object of the game is to circle the board until you have landed on all 12 of the Surf Spots. By landing on other squares you either collect or pay money depending on the instructions. There are also Trivia Challenge squares that tests your knowledge of surfing. The winner is the first player to land on all 12 Surf Spots.

Back in the late 1700’s. Two North-American fur trading corporations compete to expand their routes: the Hudson’s Bay Company, based in London (represented by red trading post cards), and the North West Company of Montreal (represented by blue trading post cards). Players mount expeditions to establish trading posts and earn money by trading pelts.

Columbia is a fast-paced card-management, action-selection game. The game material is composed of cards (expedition cards and trading post cards, both relating to traps, barters, canoes and sales), cubes representing animals and furs (beaver, wolf and bear) and coins.

The game is divided into 13 turns. Each turn is divided into 3 phases. Each phase is performed simultaneously by all players.

The richest player at the end wins.

Players move around the board trying to acquire Aces and Face cards, trying to collect 4 of a kind or 4 from one suit. To move around the board, you flip up the top card from the deck. If it is a number, you can move that many spaces either direction on the board. If it is an ace or face card, you move to the space with that card and collect it into your hand from the board.

The board has 4 types of spaces. It either has a specific card that you can collect, or is a duel space, where you pick a player and each of you pick a card off the top of the deck, with the higher card getting to take a card from the one drawing the lower card, or a higher/lower space, where you guess if the next card in the deck will be higher or lower than the last card drawn, or Suit Match, where you draw the next card and if it matches the suit of the space you are on, you can take a card of that suit into your hand.

This is a game published around 80's-90's in Taiwan. This is a rolling dice game and combines with knowledge of traffic safety. Once a player goes to Taipei, the game ends and winner is the one who has the most points.

The dices and player tokens are made of rubber. Children can use them as erasers.

Game of financial operations
Accionista mains shareholder in Spanish
Board similar to Monopoly, but include option as Tax Heaven Bonds, Takeover Bid.

The game consists of two to four players and a referee Exchange. Each player has a card of one color and 28 bars of the same color of your tab. Players are placed in the outlet box and go out one by one. Every time you come to a square that represented an action and has no slug, such action the referee should make the Exchange compulsorily the Parquet and all players will bid for it, the more money that will stay with her . The more shares you have the same group may be charged when an opponent gets there.

In the game look not only the number of shares of the same group but it must also look at what makes the index Roulette, which will be on the game board represented by - x - y - z -.

"Who knows Augsburg - The Original City Quiz"

Do You know Yor city or region? With over 500 questions about Augsburg.

The Quizmaster draws a card and asks a question. Plyayers bets correct answer with A/B/C/D-cards face-down or use their joker card. Correct answer scores points and player may continue answering. Wrong answer eliminates player from the session.
Game last until there are no players or the session is over.

Player with the most points is the winner.

Virtuoso is a music theory board game. Players compete against each other by successfully answering trivia questions about music history, composition, listening comprehension, and theory. Not for the faint of heart, Virtuoso is a competitive, yet educational game geared for high school and college musicians to expand their knowledge and show off their mad skills.
(source: calebheisey.com - with permission from the designer/site owner)

The game debuted at the 2012 Collab Game Board Competition hosted by the Philadelphia Museum of Art (http://www.philamuseum.org/collab/).

Blocks in the Pacific is a new concept game covering the whole Pacific Campaign from the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor (Dec 7th 1941) till the atomic blast in Nagasaki, August 1945.

Developed on wooden blocks and cubes system, over an astonishing 172x61cm full laminated multicolor map-board, there's not any paper component, but the Manual.
All the over 500 wooden/plastic components have been created by the best Italian artisinal industry and painted "A buratto", a technique usually adopted for painting car parts and accessories.

HISTORICAL BACKGROUND
On Dec 7th 1941, without a declaration of war the Japanese Empire launched a devastating surprise attack against the US and the British forces in the Pacific.

BLOCKS IN THE PACIFIC recalls, in game form, the most decisive battles fought in the Pacific Theater, from the Pearl Harbor strike in December 1941 to the atomic blast over Japan in August 1945..

BLOCKS IN THE PACIFIC is a game for 1-4 players, 1-2 control the Allies and the other 1-2 control the Japanese Empire.
Although based on history, players in command of the two factions can modify the evolution of World War 2 in the Pacific.

RULES INTRODUCTION
The rules are divided into three major sections which can be learned one at a time.
The first section is the BASIC GAME RULES which introduces the basic concepts and enables players to start playing the game without too many rules to remember.
Then the ADVANCED GAME RULES provide more specific and detailed rules for an enhanced realism, such as the use of Fuel and the Advanced Production System.
Finally, for those players who want to get the best out of the game, OPTIONAL RULES can be added as desired.
The Optional Rules include Technology Research, Strategic warfare, Amphibious Invasions, Parachute Assaults…

SCALE: A hexagon is approximately 53 miles (70 Km) across.
A turn is 1 month long.
A full strength counter represents 300 planes, 300 Tanks, or 30,000 men, depending on the type unit, equipment and nationality.

FOG OF WAR: The game can be played with the Fog of War on (wooden blocks are placed on the map in such a way the opponent player can not see them) OR with Fog of War OFF (all units are visible).

Language: English and Italian
Genre: Operational, Strategic
Turns: Turn-Based
Complexity: Basic to Advanced, depending on which rules are used and on Scenario Lenght
Period: World War II

SCENARIOS
With over 300 units counters and 300 different resource points of various color, players can enjoy hours of fun by playing the full 1941 DAY OF INFAMY Campaign, or one of the 5 others 6-turns scenarios.

Every scenario has different Victory conditions and length, with a playing time from 1 to 20 turns.

item.description:
TIME of DECISIONS is the last game of the Blocks Series from VentoNuovo Games.

It covers the early years before WW2, including war in Ethiopia, Spain, Aunschluss, Invasion of Cechoslovakia...

TIME of DECISIONS is a game of World War II conflict simulation at the strategic level. It recalls the most decisive battles fought in Europe, Africa and Asia from the beginning of the invasion of Ethiopia, in summer 1936 until the dramatic end in Berlin in spring 1945. Although based on historical events and battles, the players in command of the two factions can modify the evolution of World War II.

The game is recommended for two or more players, up to 6: one/three control the Allies, and the other one/three control Germany and the other Axis powers. 
The game is furthermore suitable for solitary play: the single player just controls both sides. In this case, a play with Fog of War is suggested.

Developed with a system of wooden blocks and cubes and played out over an astonishing 125x87 cm (49"x34") full laminated multicolor mapboard, the only paper component in the box is the rules manual. In total, more than 600 wooden/plastic components have been created by the best Italian artisinal industry and painted "A buratto", a technique usually adopted for painting car parts and accessories.

The rules are divided into three major sections which can be learned one at a time:
• The Basic Game Rules introduce the basic concepts and enable players to start playing the game without too many rules to remember.
• The Advanced Game Rules provide more specific and detailed rules for enhanced realism, such as the use of Fuel and the Advanced Production System.
• The Optional Rules are for those who want to get the most out of the game, with rules for Technology Research, Strategic Warfare with the bombing of Germany and U-boat campaigns in the oceans, Amphibious Landings, Airborne Assaults, and more.

In TIME OF DECISIONS, a hexagon is approximately 53 miles (70 km) across, a turn is 1 month long, and a full-strength counter represents a major military formation (normally corps size) with 300 planes, 300 tanks, or 30,000 men, depending on the unit type, equipment, nationality, etc. The game can be played with "Fog of War" on (with the faces of wooden blocks hidden from the opponent) or off (all units are visible).

Players can compete starting from 1936 Campaign, in one of four six-turn scenarios or one of the shorter, easy-to-learn scenarios. Each scenario has different victory conditions and length, with a playing time from 1 to 99 turns.

name.value: Post Time Fast Action Horse Racing Game

item.description:
Objective: make most money
acting by turns

You have an eight race series in which to accumulate assets, through buying horses and betting them to win! And, of course, your stable of winning horses can net you big purse money. The board provided sets the odds, purse money and payoffs for each race. If you play your cards right you will be the richest owner at the track.

name.value: Rivet Wars: El Frente del Este

item.description:
Rivet Wars is a miniatures boardgame that springs forth from the warped imagination of Ted Terranova - set on a world that never quite left World War I but with crazy technology like walking tanks, diesel powered armor, unicycled vehicles and armor plated cavalry!

Don't let the cute visuals fool you, it's a world full of angst, war-torn camaraderie and dark humor.

Rivet Wars is at its heart a strategy game, with both players deploying units each round to counter the threats set forth by their opponent and stay one tactical step ahead.

Heavily influenced by Ted's experience working on RTS games like Rise of Nations, players gather resources (bunkers and capture points) and use these to deploy streams of new units!

There's an ebb and flow on the tactical landscape and you can stock up surprises for your opponent to be unleashed even as he thinks he's winning!

item.description:
Old King Fafnir has no heir to his kingdom, a problem he means to solve by marrying off his daughter Princess Jezabelelle. Only there is one problem with this plan: the princess that being that the princess is such a spoiled rotten, cold hearted, ill tempered, foul mouthed, back stabbing wretch of a woman that no good, respectable knight or noble in his right mind would ever consider such a horrible fate.

Then he was struck with a flash of inspiration; he declared a that joust tournament be held for all eligible bachelors of certain royal status to participate, the prize for the victor being the Princess Jezabelle's hand in marriage.

No one signed up.

Desperate, the king hastily opened the enrollment wide open so that any man in the kingdom may participate in the tournament. The applicants began flowing in. Unfortunately for the king, those who did sign up are not so good, respectable, or in their right mind (or even human for that matter.) But it is too late for the king to do anything about it now, the joust must go on!

Fool's Joust is a card based system where players randomly draw their character and the opponents whom they will face in combat. Each turn the player use dice to engage in three rounds of combat, the character who scores the most hits or remains in their saddle wins. Players win a reward card for each successful combat; the first player to collect a predetermined number of reward cards wins the game.

Play as an interdimensional cowboy on the move searching for unique cows. You've come across "The Field", a plane that seems to attract 4 particular monstrous Moos! But these Moos are difficult to capture and you need special tools if you want to stand a chance against the other cowboys who have also discovered The Field.

Pull together 3 tools to specifically utilize against the different types of Moo. You can wield an EMP Rifle to take down Cyborg Moos, or trail Zombie Moos along with a Brain on a Stick. You might need a Steel Stetson to protect yourself against Dragon Moos, a Puzzle Box to trap Ghost Moos and don't leave your Faithful Companion at home, he'll help you round up any Moo you want!

Capture 25 different Moos, or get a pedigree herd of 15 on one type to win against the other cowboys.

This is a game with entry level tactical play. Choices are available in every step. It is meant to be a fun game for anyone to play and accessible to all levels of experience. Specifically, the game is designed to help bring players who have not had much experience with tactical play into the broader gaming market. The steps of the game are as follows:

Rustle: Draw the top two off of the deck, or one off the discard pile. If there are not enough cards in the deck, shuffle the discard pile, place it face down and continue.

Round-up: Wrangle cows and play action cards or sit-a-spell. If you choose to wrangle or play action cards you may play as many as you are able (including multiple sets of tools). To sit-a-spell you may discard any number of cards from your hand at once and draw that number from the deck. If you sit-a-spell you may not play cards, and you may not sit-a spell if you have played any cards.

Portal: Roll the Moo Dice. (A 6 sided die with 1 color for each Moo type and two opposite faces colored black). Place one Moo of each indicated type in the field according to the Moo Placement Rules. If all four dice show black then a Stampede has occurred.

Mosey: Move one Moo of each color in the field one space if possible. If there are no Moos in the field, or if none of the Moos can be moved, then skip this phase. If there is only one Moo of a color in the field you must still move that Moo.

After the Mosey phase, if you have more than 7 cards in hand, discard in the order you choose until you only have 7.

In English, the title means something like 'Oddballs' or 'Weirdos'.

Contents:
44 Cards
There are 22 Matching Pairs and the backs of each card are marked as traditional dominoes so you get two games for your money.

The aim is to collect matching pairs. A matched pair consists of the top half of a character and a bottom half of the same character.

In your turn, you can either ask a player for a card that you would like, or you can tell a player a card that you would like to get rid off. When your appeal fails, the next player plays. Completed matches are set aside.

The obvious end is that the winner is the one who collected the most pairs but the rules suggest that you could create 'oddballs', i.e. the wrong lower half with the wrong upper half. The one who creates the best oddball (as judged by laughter, I guess), wins.

The backs of the cards each feature a different domino piece so Dominoes can be played with the cards.

name.value: Europa: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt

item.description:
A small trivia game containing 98 questions about Europe.

Each card contains a question on the front and an answer on the backside (which is not the answer to the question on the other side of that card).

The cards are shuffled and evenly distributed to all players. One player asks a question from one of his cards; now all other players try to find the right answer on the backside of their cards. If a player has the card with the right answer he gets one point and is the next player to ask a question.

The winner is the player with the most points. The game also contains rules for solitaire play.

name.value: American Civil War Rules for an Army-level Wargame with 2mm or 6mm Miniatures

item.description:
The advent of 2mm scale figures represents a major step forward for those who wish to wargame the large-scale engagements of the past with miniatures. These rules use a groundscale of 22cm to the mile which makes it possible to model the very large areas occupied by big American Civil War battles on tables of conventional size.
 The rules use a 'Variable Length Bound' system developed by George Jeffrey. This diffres considerably from the 'fixed turn' systems but it is logical, easy to use, and gives a game a more realistic feel.

American Civil War Rules for an Army-level Wargame with 2mm or 6mm Miniatures system hinges upon one rule. Once the first set of orders have been written (called the initial battle orders). commanders may not write further orders except in response to a change in their command situation (Change of Situation). There are a total of thirteen general Changes of Situation including enemy forces appearing/changing direction, enemy opens or ceases fire on you forces, a unit underv your command rallies, falls back, or is broken.

2mm Groundscale: 1mm = 8 yards
2mm Figure Scale: 1 infantry block = 150 men, 1 skirmisher strip = 30 men, 1 cavalry block = 100 men (2 cavalry blocks dismount to form 1 infantry block leaving one horse-holder per 4 horses). 1 gun = Battery of 6 guns. Light arillery needs 1 limber, heavier batteries need a wagon as well to represent their extra caissons. Confererate artillery should be re-organised into 6 gun batteries or retained at 4 guns with 2/3 effect. A battery is assumed to have 100 men.

Players wishing to use these rules with 6mm (1/300 scale) figures should use a groundscale of 1mm = 4 yards and a 'block' frontage of 20 men.

name.value: A Thunder Upon the Land: The Battles of Narva and Poltava

item.description:
Before Hitler. Before Napoleon. Another European strong-man invaded Russia… and came to grief. He was Charles XII of Sweden. In later years, they would call it “The Great Northern War.”

Whether the blame can tagged to Swedish expansionism or Peter the Great’s desire for that warm-water capital city and “window on Europe,” the clash was a seemingly inevitable clash over who would own what in northern and eastern Europe and what shape Poland would take (if any). When the war started, it resembled something Frederick the Great would face, a “everyone against one country” conflict that saw Russia joined by Denmark/Norway and a Saxon-Poland-Lithuania combination, with others joining later, all seeking to take advantage of the 18-year old Charles XII—who was perceived to be weak and inexperienced. Like Frederick, he would parry multiple invasions and survive. Unlike Frederick, he would launch a serious invasion deep into Russia…and fall from power.

A Thunder Upon the Land looks as the Sweden vs. Russia portion of this war, with the two battles that rather started and finished the conflict. The Battle of Narva took place in 1700, as Russia and a Saxon-Polish contingent aimed to push Sweden out of the Baltic, with the Saxons threatening Riga and the Russians besieging Narva. But it was November, and Peter left his army feeling secure that his 40,000 men could bottle up and capture the 2500 Swedes holding the city. Charles rushed to relieve the city with an army that was well-drilled and well equipped, but numbered only about 8000 men. So, including the troops in the city, he would be attacking at something like 1-4 odds. And attacking in a blizzard. But the surprise and wretched weather worked to his advantage, and virtually the entire Russian army was killed or captured, along with their artillery and equipment. It was Russia’s finest force at the time, and an immediate invasion by Sweden might well have succeeded. But there was Riga and the Saxons to consider, and Charles let the moment pass.

Three years later, having knocked the Saxons out of the war, Charles turned again to Russia, who had surprised Europe by founding St. Petersburg on what was then still Swedish territory. Charles aimed for Moscow, and this time, it was a Swedish army that vanished from the map.

A Thunder Upon the Land brings you both battles of Narva and Poltava, with full color maps and over 250 die-cut counters. Each turn represents about one hour of real time and each hex represents about 500 yards. This game uses chit-draw for wing activation and allows players to make tactical choices like forming squares or deciding if their dragoons will press home charges or use the safer (but less effective) Carracole attacks, with optional rules for volley fire and desperation attacks.

Can you, as Charles XII, maintain Sweden’s status as the rising power in Europe? Can you, as Peter I, defeat the invaders and open the great city you gave your name to? The choices are yours as you refight the battles of Narva and Poltava.


 Map - One double-sided full-color 22"x34" mapsheet
 Counters - 264 full-color large 5/8" diecut pieces
 Rules length - 12 pages
 Charts and tables - 2 pages
 Complexity - Medium
 Solitaire suitability - Average

A trick taking game with a cyberpunk theme.

Players take turns playing cards in thematic suits (Android, Executive, Hacker and Ronin) then choose reward cards from a display with the players who used the highest ranked cards choosing first. Lower rank cards have special abilities which can change who wins, however, so players must choose wisely.

Players score based on their accumulated reward cards at the end of the game. There are four sets of reward cards that score based on how many of the set a player collected, and location cards that are always worth 3 points each but some of which can double the value of the collected set cards as well.

The game was originally made as a gift for a friend of the designer, themed around the stories from her web comic series (Arcana Jayne). Both sets of cards are available here to print & play.

Nintendo Ultraman Game released in 1966 by Nintendo based on the original Ultraman TV series. The city is on the brink of total destruction. Cars are ablaze, flying from collapsing freeways. Even worse: the local stores are under threat as well. Luckily, Ultraman comes to the rescue!

Ultraman Game is one of Nintendo's grey band games. The game bears the UltraQ logo. UltraQ was the first of the 'Ultra' series created by Tsuburaya Productions.

Players choose one of four Earth Defense characters and advance on the board by spinning the arrow on game board. When players land on the spaces with 'guns' the other spinner is used. This determines which monster was defeated, which earn players the corresponding card.

The race is open to graduate. Go the way of the wise Apprentices and try to get the points that will allow you to enter the University Bright Young. To get points, you must answer the questions correctly.

Be the first player (or first team) to finish university and get the enviable title of Junior Docte Rat.

There are four question categories: Petite Colle (Little Poser) the easy one where the questions are worth 5 points, Bon Mot (Good Word) the vocabulary category that can give you 5 or 10 points, Érudition contains harder questions worth 10 points and, finally, Mini-Test where questions are usually divided into three sub-questions totalling 15 points.

The object of the game is to be the first to finish the two board stages. You have to collect 40 points to finish the first part. Starting again from scratch, you need 80 points to complete the second level and win the game.

Players take turn rolling die to move their pawn and see what question category they will get.

Introduction

Trisq is a drawless connection game for two players: Red and Blue. It's played with trapezium-shaped pieces on an initially empty square board. The top and bottom edges of the board are colored red; the left and right edges are colored blue. The recommended board sizes are between 6x6 and 9x9.

All pieces are the same and only differ in color. They can be placed in any orientation, but always with the front side up. Thus, when playing on a physical board, the back side of the pieces should be marked so as to distinguish it from the front side. A square can accommodate four pieces, and no piece can be placed in a way that makes this physically impossible.

				
					Definitions

Two pieces are point adjacent if they share nothing more than a vertex, and edge adjacent if they share at least part of a side longer than a vertex.

				
					Play

Red plays first, then turns alternate. On his turn, a player must place one or two pieces of his color on empty spaces of the board. On his first turn, Red can only place one stone.

At the end of a turn, for any two point adjacent, like-colored pieces there must be at least one like-colored piece edge adjacent to both.

Passing is not allowed. Players will always have a move available and must make one.

The game is won by the player who completes a chain of edge adjacent pieces of his color touching the two opposite board edges of his color. Draws are not possible.

				
					Acknowledgements

The featured placement restriction was first used in Corey Clark's Slither. Asymmetric, variable orientation cell division was first used in Mark Steere's Tripen.

item.description:
This adaptation of the Quebec show Privé de Sens showcases the creative genius, memory, insight and general culture of the players.

To win, you must also demonstrate a great complicity juggling with words, mime coping with stress, find the link between various clues ... These are some of the challenges that await you!

There are many mini-game that the 2 teams will play. For mini-game the teams will get points.

The mini-games are:

1- Au pied de la lettre: In this game the team receive 3 letters. One player from the opposite team will ask questions and the 3 letters will be part of the answers. You get one point per correct answer given within the time limit.

2- Passez-moi l'expression: One player from the playing team is designated to use a randomply chosen sentence with mimes and make his or her teammates guess songs, characters, ads, etc, on a list.

3- Mémoire d'éléphant: The 2 teams look for 10 seconds at a board with 9 pictures. After the 10 seconds, the images get covered and a player ask questions. The answers will be the pictures previously seen.

4- Ménage à trois: 2 players from a team try to make there other teammates guess a word by each saying a word. After correctly guessing up to 7 words the team must try to guess what link together these words for another point.

5- Des pieds et des mains: This is mime game where to opposing team choose a restriction to make it a little more difficult. (Ex : you must use an object with your mimes)

6- The final game: The team with the most point gets 1 minute to play this game and the team with the fewer points gets 45 secondes. The team look at a card with 8 words for 8 seconds and tries to memorise them. Then one player from the team take the card and say one word so the other players can guess one the word from the list. Each correct answer award you a point for the final game and the team with the most points for the final game win.

Having fun with the meaning of words is the goal of the game Privé de sens!

"Asante", Swahili for "thank you", is something an African merchant might say to you after he has made a good deal, and if you prove to be the better merchant in this game, you might wind up with an "Asante" at game's end.

Asante is a two-player game set in the world of Jambo and Waka Waka with the same designer and artist as those games: Rüdiger Dorn and Michael Menzel. The players are dealers in an African marketplace, buying and selling furs, silk, jewelry, fruits, tea and salt in order to make the most money possible. During market day, they meet individuals with special abilities who can make deals not otherwise available; a player can also cause havoc for the opponent by loosing animals on his stand. If you visit one of the fifteen holy sites, you can take advantage of the special powers at those locations in addition to your normal five actions.

Asante can be played together with Jambo or its expansions to create a marketplace with even more activity among its stalls!

item.description:
What was once unthinkable has started to become a reality: Hell is freezing over. Naturally you and your fellow devils aren't pleased with this situation, so you're trying to surround yourself with as many hot things as possible in order to keep the home fires burning, so to speak. Can you end up on top down below?

In Dice Devils each player takes on the role of one of six devils, each ranked from 1 to 6 and each with a different special ability. On a turn, players roll their dice in secret, then one by one they each choose one of the hot items on offer on the table, starting with devil #1. When players have chosen the same item, then their dice and special abilities come into play to see who gets the goods. Fewer items are available each round than the number of players, so conflict must take place!

Don't think you can rely on that ability the entire game, though, as a devil's rank in Hell is never secure and the top devil might find himself demoted to Clean Freak or Problem Child. In the end, whichever devil collects the most valuable hot stuff wins!

name.value: Il Sonno Magico dei Giganti Fracassoni

item.description:
In Die verzauberten Rumpelriesen, the magician players want to find imps hiding in the leaves that cover the forest floor around them – but they must search carefully to find these imps so that they don't wake the sleeping giants guarding the land. Oh, and they'll need to search quickly, too, or else the giants will wake from the sleeping spell cast on them and run the searchers out of the forest. Who can combine speed, control and a good memory to find the imps where they hide?

To set up, players place the 16 imp tokens in the holes on the game board, cover these imps with the 85 cardboard leaves included in the game, then place one large wooden giant on each corner of the board. On a turn, the active player reveals a search card showing one of the imps. An opponent flips the sand timer, then the player uses her magic wand to push the leaves aside and (fingers crossed!) find the imp on the search card. She can use her wand to move the giants as well, but if they fall off the game board – or even so much as a single leaf falls – the giants awaken and chase the player away empty-handed. If the player reveals the target imp, though, she keeps the search card to record her find. After each search, players cover the board again and return the giants to their places. In the end, whoever has collected the most search cards wins!

Die verzauberten Rumpelriesen includes rules for cooperative play, with the players using their wands together to search for the imps one by one as they're revealed by the search cards. If the players find more than eight imps without the giants awakening, they win.

They can play it safe and choose a large block of land – scoring only a few points in the process if correct – or they can go small and pinpoint the location more precisely on one of the game boards, scoring far more points if correct, but upping their chances of scoring nothing if they miss their mark. In the end, whoever scores the most points wins.

item.description: Chapman Pro Football is made of wood and plastic - "You Actually Put the Ball in Play." Uses a "plinko" style area to determine the results of various plays. Parker Brothers eventually purchased the rights to this game and released it, with the identical board, but different box as Parker Pro Football Game, in both American and Canadian versions.

Speed-Way is the reality board game of car racing. It is a game for 2 - 6 players, and Ages 8 - Adult. The race arena is set in a 28" by 19" game board with its graphic details showing: Track lanes, Spectators, Maintenance Pits, Ticket windows, Parking lots, Repair garages, Safety fences, Race Flags, Food stores, Restrooms, and other elements of a sport racing arena.
 The board game shows a 10 track lanes for a 10 laps race with both Start and Finish lines. But players can race for 20, 30, 40, 50, or even 100 or higher laps as they desire, just by lapping each lane by multiple of 2, 3, 4, 5, or more times over. The game fully implements all the rules and regulations of an official car racing, including the use of all the different racing flags.

In Just in Time, each player tries to place his pieces on his game board faster than any other player, while leaving gaps in the right places on those boards. Ah, that's the art of the game because there are many points waiting to be scored if the highest possible numbers survive in the gaps created with your playing pieces.

This game is a game that tests the ability of players to evaluate proper on how much they give away pointwise in order to insure that players come to them to gain points, so by giving away points, the player has people coming to them to get points.

The core of the mechanics is that in a set order (unless playing simultaneous turns) a player will pick another player to beg to. The player being begged will divide up a set number of points between them and the begging player.

Play continues a set number of rounds with the player with the most amount of points winning the game.

In Potzblitz, everyone is playing at the same time, rolling their dice to complete the most lucrative tasks – or any task really as at the end of the round, the player who remains taskless pays a penalty, moving him closer to zero points.

To start the game, each player takes three dice in a single color, a claim card, and eight blitz tokens. Each round, three to five plus/minus cards are laid out based on the number of players, with +1 being the highest value and -2 being the lowest. Task cards are then laid out below each plus/minus card other than the -2; these task cards show either a sum or an image of three dice with specific pip values. Once the cards are in place, players start rolling their dice simultaneously, setting aside any they want to save while trying to match what's shown on one of the task cards.

As soon as a player meets a task with her dice, she can throw her claim card on it, which prevents others from claiming that task. Once all but one player have claimed a task, the round ends. Whoever failed to complete a task loses two blitz tokens, while everyone else loses one, holds onto the same amount, or gains one based on the plus/minus card associated with their completed task.

Players then set up a new round by dealing out new task cards and rolling dice once again. When a player has to return a blitz token but is unable to do so, the game ends and whoever holds the most blitz tokens wins.

The Season has started. This team has struggled for the last few years, falling from its glory days a decade past. A desperate GM fired the last guy and put you in charge. Half of the rabid fans here are already booing you. It's your job to prove them wrong, or else end up on a midseason bus out of town. Fortunately you've got a team of hustle players anchored by a few real stars... just the tools you need to deliver a playoff run... and maybe a Superbowl.

Call the plays, make the clutch decisions, bluff your opponents with trickery or just run the ball down their throat. Lead your players to victory.

End Zone is a football action card game designed to capture the strategy, drama, and science of american football, and distill it into quick, intuitive, exciting gameplay. Quick matches take 20-30 minutes. Double that for a full game.

First play any set cards to assign your personnel for the play... then secretly plot your play. Once revealed the cards physically line up against each other and give you the range of outcomes. No books of charts. No funky dice. No colorcoding necessary. The modified execution die (1d6) determines the play's final outcome.

item.description:
In Campfire, each player is attempting to build three campsites before any other player. The game focuses on building up campsites while using camp wrecking critters to prevent your opponents from finishing first. Campfire is a family-friendly card game designed to be quick to learn for players of all ages.

Players draw from a shared deck full of cards to help build their camp, wreck other camps, and alter game play. Taking turns, players draw a card, play cards on the table in front of them in three camps, and play camp wreckers and game changer cards to the discard. At the end of a player's turn, they must discard one card from their hand (if they have any cards left) and replenish their hand. Play continues counter-clockwise. Discards are shuffled to replenish the deck when it runs out.

Campsites consist of two comfort cards, two food cards, and are completed with a campfire card that must be the last card played on a campsite. Cards are stacked in the order they are played and only the top card of any campsite is vulnerable to camp wrecking attacks.

The first player to complete three camps wins the game.

Players in Primo want to rid themselves of cards by laying them in sequence on six stacks shared amongst all the players.

On a turn, a player has six cards in hand. In any order and as many times as the player wants, she can (1) play a card from her hand onto a stack if the number on the played card is one less than the top card of the stack, (2) move one stack onto another if the highest card of the moved stack is one less than the top card of the stack being covered, and (3) play any card from her hand onto an empty stack. A player's turn ends when she can play no more cards, possibly because she has emptied her hand! Two special cards are available with five copies of each; one forces opponents to take cards from the top of a stack and place them in their personal deck, and the other allows a player to play one or more cards at the top of the stack instead of the bottom.

Instead of playing cards on a turn, a player can return any number of cards from her hand to the bottom of her deck, then draw that many cards.

The first player to get rid of all cards in her deck and her hand wins!

Two variants are included in the rules. First, players play four rounds, and after each round all players score negative points for the number of cards left in their decks and hands, while the player who went out scores three positive points. Second, instead of ignoring the card colors (blue and yellow), you choose whether you must alternate card colors in the stacks or have only a single color of cards in each stack.

item.description:
The Walking Dead Card Game, based on Wolfgang Kramer's 6 nimmt!, features the same basic gameplay as that card game while adding six character cards and two modes of play: Survival and Hero.

To play the game, you shuffle the 104 number cards, lay out four cards face-up to start the four rows, then deal a number of cards to each player. Each turn, players simultaneously choose and reveal a card from their hand, then add the cards to the rows, with cards being placed in ascending order based on their number; each card is placed in the row that ends with the highest number that's below the card's number. When the sixth card is placed in a row, the owner of that card claims the other five cards and the sixth card becomes the first card in a new row.

In addition to a number from 1 to 104, each card has a zombie point value. In Survival mode (for 3-10 players), players want to collect as few points as possible, while in Hero mode (for 2-6 players) you want to collect more zombie points than anyone else. In Hero mode, each player has a single-use character card that can give you an extra advantage in the round in which you play it.

item.description:
Enter the world of one of the best selling video game franchises of all time in this special Street Fighter Collector’s Edition of Monopoly. Buy, sell and trade fighting arenas associated with the most iconic characters over 25 years such as Makoto in the Karate Dojo, Ryu on the Rooftops of Japan and Major Bison in the Shadaloo Headquarters.

While custom art and clever SF shout-outs are indeed a welcome addition, the best part about this customized version is the final 6 collectible Street Fighter-themed tokens, which were voted by fans. : Ryu, Major Bison, Blanka, Hadoken, Chun-Li’s Wrist Cuff and Vega’s Mask.

Custom game board features iconic fighting arenas from the Street Fighter video game franchise covering 25 years. Traditional Houses & Hotels are renamed Training Rooms and Dojos. “Bonus Stage” & “Random Select” cards replace classic Community Chest & Chance Cards.

Game description from the rule book:

You take on the role of a captain taking passengers to distant lands. You can collect points by making skilful manoeuvres, but your points can also be influenced by the elements. You have to be attentive to make sure you don't have any "stowaways" on board, because the coastguard can thwart your plans. You also have to make sure you have enough provisions. If you can overcome the challenges and get as many passengers as possible to their destination ports then you will be - with a bit of luck - the winner.

Each player is given a ship which he moves around from port to port on the wooden game board. During the game, players draw port cards showing a destination and its value. The players then can load passengers and bring them to these destinations. They have to make sure to have enough provision for all their passengers. The goal is to reach one of two objectives: either a general objective (40 VP), or a personal objective (chosen from a personal objective card when having reached at least 20 VP).

Each game round is divided into two phases: an action phase and a movement phase. During the action phase, the starting player rolls two dice and then chooses to take
A) the two actions associated with the dice results rolled or
B) take one action not associated with a dice result.
All the other player then take one single action: if the starting player chooses A) they have to choose B) and vice versa.

Possible actions are: take a port card, take a passenger/provisions card, load passenger(s), load provisions, take and execute an event card, lose 1 VP and choose any action.

During the movement phase, the active player can move his/her ship up to the number of spaces corresponding to the sum of his two dice. The other players can then move the higher of the two numbers rolled. When arriving in a destination port, players can unload passengers to gather victory points.

item.description:
Martial Arts: The Card Game is a customizable card game that uses actual martial art techniques and philosophies in creating a unique first-person experience in your card battles. Each box contains four pre-constructed decks, and each deck combines one or more martial arts to create a playstyle that represents a single distinct fighting style.

You can mix and match cards from different decks and styles to customize your fighting style to suit your own preference. Included for this purpose is the Sparring Pack: a collection of individual cards not seen in any of the other decks.

Modes of play included in the box are Normal (1v1, last man standing; legal moves only, no weapons), Anything Goes (1v1 which allows weapons and illegal moves), and Army of One (1v9, hero versus gang boss and his thugs).

The four 54-card decks in Martial Arts: The Card Game are:


 King of the Ring - Boxing
 Master of 8 Limbs - Muay Thai
 Ume and the Blade - Aikido, Okinawan Karate, Katana (weapon)
 Enter the Phoenix - Wing Chun, Jeet Kune Do, Butterfly Swords (weapon)

item.description:
Hell’s Gate is a simulation game of the Battle of the Korsun Pocket in Ukraine, during January and February of 1944. Two players direct the German and Soviet forces as they seek to capture or regain territory and inflict losses on the opposing side while minimizing their own losses. The simulation is also easily playable solitaire for those who wish to study the dynamics involved.

War games author, professor and designer Philip Sabin introduced Hell's Gate in his book, Simulating War, and this Victory Point Games edition has polished the game's original components to bring you a great simulation game experience.

Complexity: 3 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 7 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each turn is 3 days of real time, each hex is approx. 20 kilometers across, and each unit represents a brigade, division, or corps.

item.description:
Power Rangers! The evil Rita Repulsa has sent her Pudgy Pig monster to Angel Grove. It has eaten all of Angel Grove’s food supply. Ernie’s Youth Center won’t be able stay open without food. You need to save Ernie’s Youth Center Power Rangers by getting food back from Rita’s Evil Space Aliens! All of Angel Grove is counting on you Power Rangers. Game Objective: Players need to collect eight food items and bring them back to Ernie’s Youth Center to restock the food supply, and then travel back to the Command Center to regroup with Zordon!

The youngest player starts the game by rolling the die and moving the indicated number. If they make it to an Evil Space Alien Battle Location, they may stop their and do Battle. *Players do not have move the full amount on the die if they choose to stop on a Location area. After a player stops at a Location area, there turn ends. Play then continues with the player to left.

Winning the Game: The first player’s Power Ranger to drop off the eight collected food items to Ernie’s Youth Center and return to the Command Center is the winner!

item.description:
Conundrum is the exciting game where everyone plays by their own rules.

Each player has the same set of eight rules. The challenge is knowing when to play each rule, because the rules can only be played once. Played in eight rounds, every player is dealt 10 cards each round. Each player selects the rule that he/she will play by for that round, based on his/her hand. So each player will be playing the round by a different set of rules. After each round, those rules will clear and a new hand is dealt.

The object of the game is to try to play as many cards as possible each round. Every card left in a player's hand after each round is a point. The winner is the player with the fewest points after eight rounds.

This is the eleventh game in the Pocket Battle Games series from LPS, Inc.

Strategic level American Civil War on a postcard. The map of the Confederacy is divided into areas. The U.S player must strangle the Confederacy and reduce their will to continue fighting. Players use a standard deck of playing cards to activate armies (three Confederate and up to six Union) for movement and combat. Units can fight enemy armies in the same area. Combat is done by rolling 1D6, adding combat strength (for the Union) or Resistance Level (for the Confederates) and comparing results. Highest result wins. Losses are taken in retreats or in step losses.

There are up to eight turns, each of which is six months. The key mechanic is the Confederate Resistance Level (CRL). As Union armies occupy areas, the CRL falls. If the CRL falls to zero before the end of turn 8, the Union player wins, otherwise the Confederate player wins.

name.value: Front Office Football: The Card Game

item.description:
In Front Office Football: The Card Game, two coaches assemble "playbooks" consisting of offensive and defensive plays, then play an abridged game of professional football while choosing plays, rolling the dice and determining the results.

This game focuses on the interaction between two coaches, unlike the computer version, which was originally created in 1998 and has evolved through several versions.

In the card game, each team has a set of player cards with specific strengths and weaknesses. Along with your play calls, this helps determine the results of plays, and, ultimately, the winner of the game. It's assumed coaches (you and your friends) have a basic understanding of the rules of football. This is a game for those who genuinely enjoy football strategy and don't mind a relaxing evening at the card table.

While most of the cards are in the basic sets, each team has twelve specific plays (nine on offense, three on defense) that emphasize its strengths and tendencies. This will give your games the flavor of coaching a specific team without upsetting competitive balance.

Objective: be the first reaching target space '100' (get married)
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her (cute) meeple according die roll
ending on a coloured space follow instructions of the rule sheet

"Les Rois du Ring" is a card-driven miniature game with a boxing theme that was dreamed (literally) by french amateur designer "Chien Sauvage", and that he posted about on his blog. It is played on a 5x5 grid, with two miniatures and a deck of normal playing cards, with 1-8 as the main deck, and 16 cards used as hit points (8 each). Player take turn playing cards to move and attack each other on a "ring". They can interrupt each others turn to dodge or parry attacks.

A few variants exist that were released as creative commons

In Super Race, players try to be the first to complete a lap around the track, using the dice to hug corners and race as quickly as possible. Players first decide which racetrack to use on the double-sided player boards. Then they start racing!

On a turn, a player rolls the five dice, sets aside any she wants to keep, then rolls up to two more times, rerolling dice set aside, if desired. The dice depict curves or straights in three different colors, and after the player stops rolling, she chooses all the dice of one color and must use all of them to move on the track. Colored track on the player board can be moved through only with dice of the appropriate color, while any die color can be used to cross gray track; if a player can't use all movement for a color, she must choose a different color. A player cannot cross the same square twice. End your movement in a tight corner, and you take another turn immediately.

Players take turns until one reaches the finish line, which triggers the final round. After all players have taken the same number of turns, whoever has driven the farthest across the finish line wins. Variants in the rulebook include an option for oil slicks that take two dice to cross, a point system for a multi-race world championship, and a two lap race on the Indianapolis board that includes a shortcut. The challenge in this latter race is that you're still restricted from crossing the same square twice. Take special care the first time around, or else you'll be weaving like a maniac on lap two!

name.value: Deus Vult: Wargaming in the time of the Crusades

item.description:
Deus Vult are a set of miniatures rules designed to recreate battles during the period of the Crusades. The rules are designed to be played with 25-30mm miniatures on a 6'x4' table (but can be adapted for different figure and table sizes). They not only contain the principally d6 based rules (although d4 to d12 are used for duels between leaders) but also army lists for the Early Crusader States 1100-1128AD and Arab Dynasties 945-1150AD (plus some other sample units) along with several battle scenarios.

The game features:


 A pre-battle reconnaissance and deployment phase with options for subterfuge
 Alternating leader activation based on an initiative roll
 Leaders can give orders to multiple units based on their command rating
 Multi-figure stand based units
 d6 based combat
 Points based army lists
 Seven battle scenarios with rules to create your own

Biblebanz is a game that when played will increase Bible knowledge, vocabulary, and perhaps the faith of all who participate. There exist many card games for enhanced learning. A unique feature of this card game is that it consists of plastic adjustable headbands worn on the foreheads of each player. This feature makes it fun and exciting to learn about the Bible. More specifically this game relates to a method of learning about people, places and things found in the Bible in a fun and unique way. It has been said that a family that prays together stays together. I would also like to think that a family that plays together stays together. Therefore, it is the purpose of this game to bring goups of people together in the form of family, friends, or other small groups to learn about the Bible in this fun unique way, increasing ones Bible knowledge, vocabulary, and their faith in the Bible and in God. Churches and Sunday school teachers are always looking for new, fun and creative ways to teach their students about the Bible. This game will satisfy that need.

Each Biblebanz game comes with 6 headbands, 94 Bible cards, 6 blank cards, 24 chips and a timer.

This game is a game for the whole family for ages 7 and up. It is for 2 to 6 players. The Biblebanz Game Cards features things found in the Bible. Examples are: animals, food, people and bible objects. Examples are: Jesus, Noah, Ark, Fig tree, apple, church and so forth. The cards are simple enough for the whole family to join in on the fun. Each round only lasts one minute. At the start of the round you have to start the sand timer. As the time runs out, the player whose turn it is must ask yes or no questions to figure out what his card is. This will help to increase your Bible knowledge and Bible vocabulary. It's very entertaining to say the least. There are 6 blank cards to be used with a dry erase marker. These blank cards are great for young children who need easy words or Bible schoolars who want harder words to figure out. You can write whatever word you want out of the Bible on them. You will never run out of words to use this way.

Rules Of The Game:

The rules of Biblebanz are simple. Each player is dealt a single card and three chips. The player’s must then place the card on their headband without looking. The youngest player goes first. Then, play passes to the left. Set the one minute timer. Next, start asking questions in yes or no format. If you've found out your identity, you just ask, “Am I ________?” Fill in the blank with what you think you are. For each identity that you guess correctly, you discard one of your chips. If you guess your identity before the one minute timer runs out, take another card and put it in your headband. If you do not guess your identity before the timer runs out, then keep it and continue to guess on your next turn. The person to get rid of all of his or her chips is the Biblebanz winner! It's so much fun!

Great for birthday parties, bridal showers, Christian retreats, sleep overs, children's church, youth groups, Bible study groups, and more!

Biblebanz is a trademark of Christian Book And Toys LLC. ©2012 Christian Book And Toys LLC. All rights reserved. Patent Pending. Conforms to product safety standards CPIA, regulatory requirements.
